0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Condyloma acuminatum, Refractory or recurring external genital warts: INTRALESIONAL injection of 0.05 mL (250,000 units)/wart twice weekly for up to 8 wk; MAX 0.5 mL/treatment session

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: safety and effectiveness not established in pediatric patients under 18 years of age

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Condyloma acuminatum, Refractory or recurring external genital warts

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• anaphylactic sensitivity to egg protein, neomycin, mouse IgG
  • hypersensitivity to alfa interferon products

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• cardiovascular disease
  • coagulation disorders
  • diabetes mellitus with ketoacidosis
  • human blood product, may carry a risk of transmitting infectious agents and theoretically, the Creutzfeldt Jakob disease agent
  • seizure disorders
  • severe myelosuppression
  • severe pulmonary disease

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Injection site pain (10%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Loss of appetite (68%), Nausea (48%), Vomiting (3% to 29%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Arthralgia (5% to 10%), Myalgia (16% to 45%)
  • Neurologic:Dizziness (9%), Headache (10% to 31%)
  • Other:Fatigue (6% to 14%), Fever (40% to 81%), Malaise (65%), Shivering (14% to 87%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Interferon alfa-n3 is a protein that induces protein synthesis by binding to specific membrane receptors, which leads to inhibition of virus replication and suppression of cell proliferation. The agent exerts its immunomodulation effect by enhancing macrophage phagocytosis and expression of human leukocyte antigen and augmenting lymphocyte cytotoxicity.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intralesional
  • use a 30 gauge needle and inject into the base of each wart
  • do not shake

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
INTERFERONS
OVERDOSE: Data are limited. Shivers, myalgias, low grade fever and tachycardia have been reported. ADVERSE EFFECTS: "flu-like" symptoms (fever, chills, tachycardia, headache, malaise, and myalgias), hypotension, seizures, headache, lethargy, fatigue, elevated liver enzymes, leukopenia, & renal insufficiency; dysrhythmias in patients with underlying heart disease. Vomiting, diarrhea, hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia occur at high doses.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
INTERFERONS
  • Decontamination: Not indicated; broken down in the gut on oral ingestion.
  • Influenza-like illness: Treat with acetaminophen or non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents
  • Hypotensive episode: Transient, usually requires no treatment; 0.9% NaCl 10-20 ml/kg, dopamine, epinephrine if persistent
  • Monitoring of patient: CBC, hepatic & renal function; ECG, calcium, potassium if severe overdose.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
INTERFERONS
Single doses greater than 100-200 million units associated with toxicity.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to practice safe sex as drug does not prevent disease transmission.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of leukopenia, neutropenia, or thrombocytopenia.
  • Drug may cause diarrhea, dyspepsia, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, an influenza-like illness, arthralgia, myalgia, fever, or depression.
